Award.AwardTitle: Recruitment and Dynamics of the Mediator Complex

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide new insights into molecular interactions that govern how genes are turned on and off in living cells. The project focuses on a large protein complex called Mediator, which selectively turns on subsets of genes in both yeast and mammalian cells. Two central questions will be addressed. First, how does Mediator select and turn on its gene targets? Second, how does Mediator action in yeast compare to its action in mammalian cells? The comparative approach used in this project will have broad impact on fundamental understanding of gene activity in "simple" yeast versus "complex" mammalian cells. Some of the results will be in the form of "big data"--large data sets that describe molecular interactions across an entire genome--and these will be deposited in public archives where they can be freely accessed by scientists and the public. In addition, the project will provide training for undergraduates, a postdoctoral fellow, and two female graduate students, one of whom is a member of an underrepresented minority.

The Mediator protein complex consists of over twenty interacting proteins and is found in all cells with nuclei (eukaryotes). Mediator is known to play a critical gene activating role via association with the machinery responsible for RNA synthesis (transcription). However, how Mediator locates its gene targets and exactly what it does when it finds them, are not completely understood. This project will address these issues in three aims. The first will test the idea that proteins belonging to the general transcription machinery help Mediator to find its targets. The approach will be to compare Mediator association with its targets in normal yeast cells and in mutants in which components of the general transcription machinery are impaired, using a method called ChIP-seq that identifies where proteins associate with DNA across an entire genome. The second aim will follow up on previous results that suggested that Mediator association with different targets is related to differential dynamics--how fast Mediator finds its targets and how often and rapidly it leaves again. This idea will be tested using variations of chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP, the basis of ChIP-seq) that provide information on binding dynamics. These first two aims will be done using the model system of baker's yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae), which is easy to work with but is quite similar to mammalian cells in its molecular makeup. In the third aim, the effect of impairing function of specific subunits of Mediator in mammalian cells on gene transcription will be tested by "knocking down" expression of those subunits and measuring the effect on genome-wide transcription by high throughput sequencing. In yeast, this has been a productive strategy for understanding how Mediator structure relates to its function. Comparing the results obtained in mammalian cells will reveal similarities and differences with yeast, and thereby reveal the value and limitations of knowledge gained using the yeast system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

            The focus of this project was the Mediator complex.  Mediator consists of over twenty proteins in a single complex, and is found in all eukaryotic cells (cells having nuclei, as opposed to bacteria, which lack nuclei).  Mediator is critical to gene transcription, in which RNA Polymerase II (Pol II) copies DNA into messenger RNA, which codes for the proteins that perform most of the structural and functional tasks needed for cellular life. For this project, we employed the model organism baker’s yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae), which greatly resembles higher organisms including ourselves at the molecular level but is experimentally much simpler to work with. 

Two main objectives were addressed in this project. The first was aimed at understanding at a molecular level how Mediator is recruited to its target genes to participate in activating transcription. Mediator can be divided into four modules, based on structural and genetic criteria, and previous work from ourselves and others had indicated that the “tail” module was important in the recruitment of Mediator by activator proteins; the latter are proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences to initiate transcription activation. In the current funding period, we used high throughput methods, including chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by Next Generation sequencing, to show that yeast in which Mediator lacks all three subunits in the “tail module triad” exhibit greatly reduced association of both Mediator and Pol II across the genome. However, in spite of this impaired Mediator function, these yeast survive and show only moderate growth defects, raising the question of how Mediator is recruited when its interaction with activator proteins is defective. We hypothesized that interactions between Mediator (lacking tail module subunits) and other components of the transcription machinery might be sufficient to facilitate its association with gene promoters. To test this idea, we used genetic methods to temporarily deplete three important components of the “pre-initation complex”—the basic transcription machinery—from gene promoters, and determine how Mediator association was affected. We found that depletion of Pol II or Taf1, which is part of the TFIID complex that helps to bring Pol II to promoters, caused a strong reduction in Mediator association with gene promoters. Depletion of TBP, which is also part of the TBP complex and is essential for Pol II association with promoters, allowed Mediator to be recruited by activators but prevented its transit from the initial recruitment site (where the activators bind) to the promoter (where Pol II begins to transcribe the DNA). We also found that under some circumstances, Mediator remains associated with genes that are repressed by environmental stress, while Pol II is no longer associated. The mechanism behind this remains unknown.

The second objective addressed in the project was the role of Mediator in Ty1 retrotransposition in yeast. Ty1 is a mobile DNA element that is present in multiple copies in the yeast genome. This element is transcribed into RNA, transported from nucleus to cytoplasm, reverse transcribed into DNA, and at low frequency (about one in ten million cell divisions), insert itself into a new genomic location. We discovered that Mediator exerts a complex influence on this process. Deletion of tail module subunits reduces retrotransposition frequencies to undetectable levels, while the frequency is increased by deletion of either of two “head module” subunits. We determined the mechanism behind these differential effects: the Ty1 element encodes two distinct transcripts, one of which encodes all of the functions necessary for retrotransposition, while the other, normally transcribed at very low levels, inhibits retrotransposition. We found that the ratio of these transcripts varies depending on which Mediator subunits are absent in a manner concordant with the effects on retrotransposition. The promoters for these two Ty1 transcripts differ in some notable molecular features, and we hypothesize that the different Mediator subunits are differentially sensitive to these features. Further work will be needed to test this hypothesis.

 

Broader impact

            The results from this work were disseminated via three research papers and another that is in preparation, as well as presentations at several scientific conferences.  Some of the experiments provided large data sets that have been deposited in public archives where they are freely accessible by scientists and the public.  The project also contributed to the training of two graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow, including two female and one minority student; and also five undergraduate students, four of whom were female and one of whom was an underrepresented minority student.
